revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|2008|chess}} Events in [[chess]] during the year 2008:
==Events== (Top events in '''bold''')
===January=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE January 2008 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2799 || +14 |- | 2 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2799 || –2 |- | 3 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2780 || +11 |- | 4 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexander Morozevich]]|RUS}} || 2765 || +10 |- | 5 || 12 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Peter Svidler]]|RUS}} || 2763 || +31 |- | 6 || 7 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]]|AZE}} || 2760 || +8 |- | 7 || 10 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexei Shirov]]|ESP}} || 2755 || +16 |- | 8 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Peter Leko]]|HUN}} || 2753 || −2 |- | 9 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vassily Ivanchuk]]|UKR}} || 2753 || −36 |- | 10 || 9 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2739 || −2 |} * '''January 1''' – [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia) gains 14 [[Elo rating system|rating points]] to move from number three to head the [[FIDE]] top 100 players lists at 2799. [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India) also at 2799 drops from first to second as he played fewer rated games in the previous reporting period. [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria) is third at 2780. [[Vassily Ivanchuk]] (Ukraine) loses 36 points to drop from number two to number nine. As on the [[2007 in chess#October|previous list]], a rating of 2627 is required to place in the top 100.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4349|date=30 December 2007|publisher=[[chessbase.com]]|title=Kramnik and Anand lead the January 1st 2008 FIDE ratings|accessdate=2008-01-20}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.fide.com/ratings/toparc.phtml?cod=121|title=FIDE Top 100 Players January 2008|date=January 2008|publisher=FIDE|accessdate=2008-01-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080102035229/http://www.fide.com/ratings/toparc.phtml?cod=121 |archivedate = 2008-01-02}}</ref> * '''January 6''' – 83rd [[Hastings International Chess Congress|Hastings International Congress]] ends in three-way tie between GM [[Vadim Malakhatko]] (Belgium), GM [[Nidjat Mamedov]] (Azerbaijan), and GM [[Valeriy Neverov]] (Ukraine). Earlier in the tournament IM Simon Williams (England) achieved a performance that should qualify him for the [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] title ([[Elo rating system|rating]] temporarily over 2500, he already had the required [[grandmaster norm|norms]]).<ref name="twic687"> {{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic687.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 687|date=7 January 2008|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * January 6 – 50th [[Reggio Emilia chess tournament|Reggio Emilia]] won by GM [[Zoltán Almási]] (Hungary).<ref name="twic687"/> * January 7 – 2nd [[Association of Chess Professionals|ACP]] World Rapid Cup in [[Odessa]] won by GM [[Teimour Radjabov]] (Azerbaijan) over GM [[Alexander Grischuk]] (Russia) in a [[fast chess|blitz]] playoff.<ref name="twic687"/><ref> {{citation|last=Savinov|first=Misha|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4369|title=Radjabov wins ACP World Rapid Cup in Odessa|date=8 January 2008|periodical=Chessbase News}}</ref> * January 9 – Asian Team Championships in [[Visakhapatnam]] men's and women's gold medal won by [[Chess in China|China]], with India winning silver and [[Vietnam]] bronze in both events.<ref name="twic690"/> * January 11 – 2007/8 [[Australian Chess Championship|Australian Championship]] in [[Parramatta]] won by IM [[Stephen Solomon]] placing second (top finisher among Australians). GM [[Dejan Antic]] (Serbia) won the tournament.<ref name="twic688"/> * January 12 – 33rd Ciudad de Sevilla won by GM [[Karen Movsziszian]] (Armenia).<ref name="twic688"> {{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic688.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 688|date=14 January 2008|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * January 13 – 5th Estonia–Finland match on 100 boards in [[Tallinn]] won by Estonia 60.5–28.5. (Finland was short of players, and only 89 games were played.)<ref name="twic690"/> * January 19 – [[Venezuelan Chess Championship|Venezuelan Championship]] in [[San Felipe, Yaracuy|San Felipe]] won by IM [[Eduardo Iturrizaga]] 10/11. This is IM Eduardo Iturrizaga's third consecutive championship title. WIM [[Maria Ubaldo]] won the women's championship for the second year in a row, 6.5/9.<ref name="twic690"/> * January 21 – 68th [[Armenian Chess Championship|Armenian Championship]] in [[Yerevan]] won for the third time and the second consecutive year by GM [[Karen Asrian]] on tie-break over six-time champion GM [[Artashes Minasian]]. Both scored 8/12 in a field of 13 with 11 GMs. WIM [[Lilit Galojan]] is the 62nd women's champion on tie-break over WIM Siranush Andriasian.<ref name="twic690"/> * January 22 – [[Belarusian Chess Championship|Belarus Championship]] in [[Minsk]] won by GM [[Alexei Fedorov]] with 9.5/13.<ref name="twic690"/> * January 24 – [[Viswanathan Anand]] named [[CNN-IBN]]'s Indian Sportsperson of 2007 in recognition of his 20-year career and 2007 World Championship title.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/grandmaster-anand-is-2007s-top-sportsman/57251-5.html Grandmaster Anand is 2007's top sportsman]. Retrieved 2008-01-25.</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4409|title=Anand elected Indian Sportsperson of the Year 2007|date=24 January 2008|accessdate=2008-01-25}}</ref> * January 25 – 115th [[New Zealand Chess Championship|New Zealand Championship]] in [[Auckland]] won by GM [[Murray Chandler]] with 9/11.<ref name="twic690"/> * '''January 27''' – [[Corus chess tournament|Corus]] 2008 (Wijk aan Zee) A-group (category 20) won by GM [[Levon Aronian]] (Armenia) and GM [[Magnus Carlsen]] (Norway), tied at 8/13. This is the second time that the 25-year-old Aronian shared first place at this tournament. Carlsen is only 17 years old.<ref name="twic690"> {{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic690.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 690|date=28 January 2008|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * January 28 – [[Azerbaijan Chess Championship|Azerbaijan Championship]] in [[Baku]] won by GM [[Rauf Mammadov]] with 7/9.<ref name="twic691"/> * January 29 – [[Croatian Chess Championship|Croatian Championship]] in [[Split (city)|Split]] won by GM [[Hrvoje Stevic]] with 8/12.<ref name="twic691"/> * January 31 – 6th Gibraltar Gibtelecom Chess Festival won by GM [[Hikaru Nakamura]] (USA) in a 2–0 playoff against GM [[Bu Xiangzhi]] (China) after both finished with 8/10. IM [[Zhao Zong-Yuan]] became Australia's youngest ever GM at age 21 by scoring 6 in the first 9 rounds on the way to 6.5/10.<ref name="twic691"> {{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic691.html|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 691|date=4 February 2008|publisher=London Chess Center|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4427|title=Nakamura beats Bu, wins Gibtel 2008|date=2 February 2008|last=Friedel|first=Frederic|author-link=Frederic Friedel|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-02-08}}</ref> * [[Cuban Chess Championship]] won by [[Yuniesky Quesada]].<ref name="twic691"/>
===February=== * February 2 – "To Gligorić with Love", a [[rapid chess]] tournament in [[Pančevo]] honors [[Svetozar Gligorić]] (Serbia) on his 85th birthday. The 85 player field includes 23 GMs, 21 IMs, 12 FMs, 4 WGMs, and 1 WIM. Five players tie for first place, with GM [[Ivan Ivanišević]] (Serbia) winning the trophy.<ref>{{citation|last=Asik|first=Josip|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4431|title=To Gligoric with Love – a legend turns 85|periodical=ChessBase News|date=6 February 2008|accessdate=2008-02-08}}</ref> * February 10 – 4th International Chess Festival Moscow Open held at the [[Russian State Social University]] won by GM [[Artyom Timofeev (chess player)|Artyom Timofeev]] 7.5/9, overtaking the tournament leader GM [[Ernesto Inarkiev]] (7/9) by beating him in the final round in a 117-move game. IM [[Anna Muzychuk]] wins the women's section with 8/9. The tournament has a 5 million [[Russian ruble|ruble]] prize fund (about US$205,760).<ref>{{citation|last=Atarov|first=Eugene|title=Artyom Timofeev wins Moscow Open 2008|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4441|date=10 February 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-02-15}}</ref><ref name="twic692">{{cite web |last=Crowther|first=Mark|date=11 February 2008|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 692|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic692.html|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * February 15 – 45th [[Indian Chess Championship|Indian Championship]] in [[Chennai]] won by GM [[Surya Shekhar Ganguly]] on tie-break over IM K Rathnakaran after both scored 9/11.<ref name="twic693"/> * February 16 – British Chess Solving Championship has a field of 33, including all title British solvers and two overseas guests. Former world solving champion [[Piotr Murdzia]] scores 59/65 to lead the field by 7½ points. [[Dolf Wissmann]] (Netherlands) and [[Jonathan Mestel]] share second place with 51½, a half-point ahead of [[John Nunn]], alone in fourth. Mestel wins his 15th championship as the highest British scorer.<ref name="twic694"/> * February 17 – Four Nations Chess Challenge in [[Oslo]] won by Sweden. England finishes second, followed by Latvia and Norway.<ref name="twic693">{{cite web |last=Crowther|first=Mark|date=18 February 2008|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 693|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic693.html|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * February 19 – European Senior Team Championship in [[Dresden]] won by the Czech Republic team headed by [[Vlastimil Jansa]].<ref name="twic694"/> * February 22 – [[Aeroflot]] Open in Moscow won by 17-year-old GM [[Ian Nepomniachtchi]] (Russia) with the score 7/9. Regarded as the strongest open tournament in the world, the prize fund is US$200,000 with $30,000 for the winner.<ref name="twic694"/><ref>{{citation|title=Nepomniachtchi wins Aeroflot Open 2008|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4469|periodical=ChessBase News|date=22 February 2008|accessdate=23 February 2008}}</ref> * February 23 – 79th [[German Chess Championship|German Championship]] in [[Bad Woerishofen]] won by GM [[Daniel Fridman]].<ref name="twic694">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|date=25 February 2008|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 694|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic694.html|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * February 24 – 60th [[Polish Chess Championship|Polish Women's Championship]] in [[Kraków]] won by IM [[Monika Soćko]].<ref name="twic694"/>
===March=== * March 1 – Icelandic Team Championship won by Taflfélag Reykjavikur over Hellir A. Taflfélag Reykjavikur included six GMs and 3 IMs. The [[World Junior Chess Championship|World Junior Champion]] [[Ahmed Adly]] (Egypt) achieved the top board one performance, playing for Hellir A and scoring 3/3 (100%) with a performance rating of 3017.<ref>{{citation|last=Bojkov|first=Dejan|date=4 March 2008|title=Winner Takes It All in Iceland|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4488|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-03-04}}</ref> * '''March 7''' – [[Linares chess tournament|Morelia/Linares]] won by [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India) scoring 8½/14, a half-point ahead of [[Magnus Carlsen]] (Norway).<ref>{{citation|last=Monokroussos|first=Dennis|title=Linares R14: All games drawn, Anand wins Super-GM|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4493|publisher=ChessBase News|date=7 March 2008|accessdate=2008-03-09}}</ref><ref name="twic696">{{cite web|last=Crowther|first=Mark|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 696|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic696.html|date=10 March 2008|accessdate=2008-09-16}}</ref> * March 2 – [[Romanian Chess Championship|Romanian Championship]] in [[Cluj-Napoca]] won by GM [[Vladislav Nevednichy]] on tie-break with five players at 7/9.<ref name="twic696"/> * March 8 – 126th Varsity Match between the [[Cambridge University Chess Club]] and the [[Oxford University Chess Club]] held in London. The match is drawn 4–4, leaving Cambridge in the all-time series lead with 56 wins to Oxford's 49, with 14 drawn matches.<ref name="twic696"/><ref>{{citation|last=Saunders |first=John |title=126th Varsity Chess Match: Oxford University v Cambridge University, 8 March 2008 |url=http://www.bcmchess.co.uk/news/varsity2008.html |date=10 March 2008 |periodical=[[British Chess Magazine]] |accessdate=2008-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314001229/http://www.bcmchess.co.uk/news/varsity2008.html |archivedate=March 14, 2008 }}</ref> * March 9 – 65th [[Polish Chess Championship]] in [[Lublin]] won by GM [[Bartosz Soćko]] with 9/13.<ref name="twic696"/> * March 9 – Finnish Team Championship won by Matinkylä for the first time since 1993, after placing second four consecutive times.<ref name="twic696"/> * March 12 – 65th [[Georgian Chess Championship|Georgian Women's Championship]] in [[Tbilisi]] won by IM [[Nana Dzagnidze]] over WGM [[Salome Melia]] in a rapid playoff after both finished with 9/12.<ref name="twic697">{{cite web|last=Crowther|first=Mark|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 697|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic697.html|date=17 March 2008|accessdate=18 March 2008}}</ref> * March 18 – Russian U-20 Championship in [[Saint Petersburg]] * March 20 – Atatürk International Women's Masters in [[Istanbul]] won by 14-year-old WGM [[Hou Yifan]] (China) scoring 7/9 to finish a full point ahead of GM [[Pia Cramling]] (Sweden).<ref>{{citation|title=Atatürk Istanbul: Hou Yifan wins Atatürk Masters|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4526|periodical=ChessBase News|date=21 March 2008|accessdate=2008-03-26}}</ref><ref name="twic698">{{cite web|last=Crowther|first=Mark|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 698|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic698.html|date=24 March 2008|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * March 24 – 72nd [[Bulgarian Chess Championship|Bulgarian Men's Championship]] in [[Plovdiv]] won by GM [[Vasil Spasov (chess player)|Vasil Spasov]] scoring 9½/13. WFM [[Elitsa Raeva]] wins the 57th Women's Championship also in [[Plovdiv]], scoring 9/11.<ref name="twic698"/> * March 24 – [[Danish Chess Championship|Danish Championship]] in [[Silkeborg]] won by GM [[Peter Heine Nielsen]] who scored 7/9 in his first appearance in the championship in five years.<ref name="twic698"/> * March 24 – [[Doeberl Cup]] Premier in [[Canberra]] won by GM [[Varuzhan Akobian]] (USA) scoring 7½/9.<ref name="twic698"/> * March 24 – [[Welsh Chess Championship|Welsh Championship]] in [[Cardiff]] won jointly by IM Leighton Williams and FM James Cobb scoring 6/7.<ref name="twic699">{{cite web|last=Crowther|first=Mark|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 699|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic699.html|date=31 March 2008|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref><ref name="twic700"/> * March 27 – [[Iranian Chess Championship|Iranian Championship]] won by GM [[Ehsan Ghaem Maghami]] scoring 12/13. Although Iran has five GMs he was the only GM in the event as the others declined to play due to lack of a cash prize. WIM [[Atousa Pourkashiyan]] wins the Women's Championship scoring 8½/11 to top a twelve-player field including one WGM, two WIMs, and four WFMs.<ref name="twic699"/><ref>{{citation|last=Akbarinia|first=Arash|title=Iranian Chess Championship 2008|url=http://chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4538|date=30 March 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-03-31}}</ref> * March 28 – [[Melody Amber|Amber Rapid and Blindfold]] in [[Nice]] won by GM [[Levon Aronian]]. The blindfold section was a three-way tie, with Aronian, GM [[Vladimir Kramnik]], and GM [[Alexander Morozevich]] all scoring 6/11. Aronian won the rapid section with 7½/11, 2 points ahead of four players tied for second. The prize fund is €216,000 (approximately US$336,000).<ref>{{citation|title=Melody Amber: Aronian wins with 2½ point lead|url=http://chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4536|date=27 March 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-03-31}}</ref> * March 28 – [[Serbian Chess Championship|Serbian Championship]] in [[Mataruška]] won by GM [[Ivan Ivanišević]] scoring 9/13.<ref name="twic699"/> * March 30 – 67th [[Georgian Chess Championship|Georgian Championship]] won by GM [[Levan Pantsulaia]] by beating IM [[Giorgi Margvelashvili (chess player)|Giorgi Margvelashvili]] in the final. The championship is a knockout event with rapid playoff tie-break. Marvelashvili earned a [[Grandmaster norm|GM norm]].<ref name="twic699"/>
===April=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; margin-left: 1em; float: right;" |+ FIDE April 2008 Top Ten ! Rank !! Prev !! Player !! Rating !! Chng |- | 1 || 2 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Viswanathan Anand]]|IND}} || 2803 || +4 |- | 2 || 1 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Vladimir Kramnik]]|RUS}} || 2788 || −11 |- | 3 || 4 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Alexander Morozevich]]|RUS}} || 2774 || +9 |- | 4 || 3 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Veselin Topalov]]|BUL}} || 2767 || −13 |- | 5 || 13 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Magnus Carlsen]]|NOR}} || 2765 || +32 |- | 6 || 10 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Levon Aronian]]|ARM}} || 2763 || +24 |- | 7 || 6 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Shakhriyar Mamedyarov]]|AZE}} || 2752 || −8 |- | 8 || 12 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Teimour Radjabov]]|AZE}} || 2751 || +16 |- | 9 || 5 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Peter Svidler]]|RUS}} || 2746 || −17 |- | 10 || 8 || align=left|{{flagathlete|[[Peter Leko]]|HUN}} || 2741 || −12 |} * '''April 1''' – [[Viswanathan Anand]] (India) regains the top spot on the FIDE ratings list as [[Vladimir Kramnik]] (Russia) falls to second place. Seventeen-year-old [[Magnus Carlsen]] (Norway) enters the top ten for the first time, jumping eight spots to move to fifth, just 38 rating points below first. [[Sergey Karjakin]] (Ukraine) is the next highest rated junior, 13th overall with a 2732 rating. [[Judit Polgár]] (Hungary) is the only woman in the top one hundred, with her 2709 rating earning 22nd place. [[Humpy Koneru]] (India) is the second ranked woman rated over a hundred points lower at 2603. [[Hou Yifan]] (China) moves up one position to fourth on the women's list at age fourteen years and one month. [[Antoaneta Stefanova]] (Bulgaria) makes the largest jump on the women's list, gaining 74 rating points to climb from 24th up to 6th.<ref>{{citation|title=Anand leads April 1st 2008 FIDE ratings, Carlsen fifth|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4546|date=2 April 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-03-02}}</ref> * April 1 – ''[[Chess Informant]]'' publishes its one-hundredth issue.<ref>[http://www.chessvibes.com/personal/chess-informant-no-100-interview-aleksandar-matanovic/ "Chess Informant no. 100"] an interview with editor-in-chief [[Aleksandar Matanović]] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405194748/http://www.chessvibes.com/personal/chess-informant-no-100-interview-aleksandar-matanovic/ |date=April 5, 2008 }}</ref> * April 4 – [[Turkish Chess Championship|Turkish Championship]] in [[Ankara]] won by GM [[Mikhail Gurevich (chess player)|Mikhail Gurevich]] scoring 11½/13, a half-point ahead of GM [[Suat Atalık]].<ref name="twic700">{{citation|last=Crowther|first=Mark|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 700|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic700.html|date=7 April 2008|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * April 5 – 9th Internet Tournament Ciudad de Dos Hermanas won by defending champion [[Jorge Sammour-Hasbun]], scoring 15/17. Twenty-five-year-old Sammour-Hasbun (Zamora) is the former [[World Youth Chess Championship|World Under-10 Champion]] but has no [[FIDE]] title. Held on the [[Internet Chess Club]], this event is the largest and most important internet chess tournament. Total prize fund is €7700, with €2000 for the winner.<ref name="twic700"/> * April 9 – [[Serbian Chess Championship|Serbian Women's Championship]] in [[Kać]] won by WGM [[Andjelija Stojanovic]] scoring 8½/11.<ref name="twic701"/> * April 13 – [[Dutch Chess Championship|Dutch Championship]] in [[Hilversum]] is twelve-player [[round-robin tournament]] with an average rating of 2536 (Category XII). Twenty-one-year-old GM [[Daniël Stellwagen]] had a half-point lead with 7/10 going into the final round, but loses to 23-year-old GM [[Jan Smeets]] in the decisive game, giving Smeets the final score 7½/11 for the half-point win and €10,000. [[Peng Zhaoqin]] scores 8½/9 to win the [[Dutch Chess Championship|Dutch Women's Championship]] in Hilversum by 1½ points. This is Zhaoqin's ninth consecutive women's championship and her tenth overall.<ref name="twic701">{{cite web |last=Crowther|first=Mark|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 701|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic701.html|date=14 April 2008|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Jan Smeets wins the Dutch Championship 2008|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4567|date=13 April 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-04-17}}</ref> * April 13 – 2nd Ruy Lopez Masters in [[Mérida, Spain|Mérida]] won by GM [[Michael Adams (chess player)|Michael Adams]] (England) scoring 5½/7 to finish a half-point ahead of [[Zhang Pengxiang]]. The tournament was an eight player round-robin with an average rating of 2616 (FIDE category 15).<ref name="twic701"/><ref>{{citation|title=Michael Adams wins Second Ruy López International in Mérida|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4566|date=13 April 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-04-14}}</ref> * April 14 – Russian Team Championships in [[Sochi]] won by Ural Yekaterinburg. Composed of GMs [[Teimour Radjabov]] (2751), [[Alexei Shirov]] (2755), [[Gata Kamsky]] (2732), [[Alexander Grischuk]] (2711), [[Vladimir Malakhov (chess player)|Vladimir Malakhov]] (2689), [[Vladimir Akopian]] (2700), [[Alexey Dreev]] (2633), and [[Alexander Motylev]] (2644), it is the only team with an average rating over 2700. The Women's Team Championship is won by Finec Saint Petersburg, composed of [[Ekaterina Korbut]], [[Viktorija Čmilytė]], [[Natalia Zhukova]], [[Julia Demina]], and [[Irina Turova (chess player)|Irina Turova]].<ref name="twic701"/><ref>{{citation|title=Russian Team Championships 2008 in Sochi|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4572|date=17 April 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-04-17}}</ref> * April 14 – 10th Dubai Open won by 14-year-old GM [[Wesley So]] (Philippines), the world's youngest GM, on tie-break over GMs [[Merab Gagunashvili]] (Georgia), [[Ehsan Ghaem Maghami]] (Iran) and [[Li Chao (chess player)|Li Chao]] (China), all with 7/9.<ref name="twic701"/> A player from Iran is expelled from the tournament over accusations of [[cheating in chess|cheating]] by receiving moves on a [[mobile phone]] sent by an accomplice using a [[chess computer]].<ref>{{citation|last=Kumar|first=Ravi|title=Wesley So wins Dubai Open, player disqualified for cheating|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4570|date=17 April 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-04-17}}</ref> * April 20 – 2007/8 [[Chess Bundesliga]] * April 20 – 14th Ciudad de Dos Hermanas Rapid won by GM [[Veselin Topalov]] (Bulgaria), defeating GM [[Francisco Vallejo Pons]] (Spain) 2½–1½ in the final match by winning the first game and drawing the rest. The first round matches of the four-player [[single elimination tournament|knockout]] [[fast chess|rapid chess]] tournament were won by Topalov over GM [[Judit Polgár]] (Hungary) 2½–1½ and Vallejo over GM [[Alexei Shirov]] (Spain) 3–1.<ref>{{citation|title=Topalov Wins Dos Hermanas Rapid|url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=4580|date=21 April 2008|periodical=ChessBase News|accessdate=2008-04-21}}</ref>
===May=== * May 4 – 9th [[European Individual Chess Championship|European Chess Championship]] in [[Plovdiv]] * May 6 – FIDE Grand Prix in [[Baku]], the first event in the [[FIDE Grand Prix 2008–2009]] * May 17 – Dutch Team Championship * '''May 18''' – [[M-Tel Masters]] in [[Sofia]]
===August=== * August 9 – 95th [[British Chess Championship|British Championship]] in [[Liverpool]] * August 17 – 8th [[European Senior Chess Championship|European Individual Senior Championship]] in [[Davos]]. * August 28 Start of [[Women's World Chess Championship 2008]]
===October=== * '''October 3 to 18''' - First [[World Mind Sports Games]] held in Beijing, China<ref>[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/4-tournaments/2900-the-first-international-mind-sports-games-imsa-cup The first international mind sports games “IMSA Cup”] [[FIDE]]</ref> * '''October 14''' – Start of [[Viswanathan Anand|Anand]]–[[Vladimir Kramnik|Kramnik]] [[World Chess Championship 2008|2008 World Championship]] match in [[Bonn]] * '''October 29''' – [[Viswanathan Anand|Anand]] draws the eleventh game of his [[World Chess Championship 2008|match]] with [[Vladimir Kramnik|Kramnik]] to retain the World Championship title by the score 6½–4½ (+3−1=7).
==Titles awarded==
===Grandmaster=== In 2008 [[FIDE]] awarded the title [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] to the following players:<ref name="FIDE 2Q2008 titles">[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/5-whats-news/1519-10-list-of-titles-approved-by-the-2nd-quarter-fide-presidential-board-2008 List of Titles Approved by the 2nd quarter FIDE Presidential Board 2008] from fide.com</ref><ref name="FIDE 3Q2008 titles">[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/2984-list-of-titles-approved-by-the-3rd-quarter-presidential-board-31-may-1-june-2008-athens-greece List of titles approved by the 3rd quarter FIDE Presidential Board 2008]</ref> {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * [[Yuriy Ajrapetjan]] (b. 1988) {{UKR}} * [[Ralf Appel]] (b. 1971) {{DEU}} * [[Axel Bachmann]] (b. 1989) {{PRY}} * [[Vinay Bhat]] (b. 1984) {{USA}} * [[Dmitry Chuprov]] (b. 1978) {{RUS}} * [[Andrey Deviatkin]] (b. 1980) {{RUS}} * [[Anton Filippov]] (b. 1986) {{UZB}} * [[Avetik Grigoryan]] (b. 1989) {{ARM}} * [[Stewart Haslinger]] (b. 1981) {{ENG}} * [[Frank Holzke]] (b. 1971) {{DEU}} {{col-break}} * [[Enamul Hossain]] (b. 1981) {{BGD}} * [[Valentin Iotov]] (b. 1988) {{BGR}} * [[Eduardo Iturrizaga]] (b. 1989) {{VEN}} * [[Miguel Llanes Hurtado]] (b. 1978) {{ESP}} * [[Konstantin Maslak]] (b. 1984) {{RUS}} * [[Jakob Meister]] (b. 1955) {{DEU}} * [[Oleg Nikolenko]] (b. 1959) {{RUS}} * [[Tomas Petrik]] (b. 1980) {{SVK}} * [[Markus Ragger]] (b. 1988) {{AUT}} * [[Eltaj Safarli]] (b. 1992) {{AZE}} {{col-break}} * [[Ivan Salgado Lopez]] (b. 1991) {{ESP}} * [[Vigen Mirumian]] (b. 1977) {{CZE}} * [[Marie Sebag]] (b. 1986) {{FRA}} * [[Dmitriy Skorchenko]] (b. 1983) {{RUS}} * [[Sergey Vokarev]] (b. 1970) {{RUS}} * [[Yuri Vovk]] (b. 1988) {{UKR}} * [[Wen Yang (chess player)|Wen Yang]] (b. 1988) {{CHN}} * [[Simon Williams (chess player)|Simon Williams]] (b. 1979) {{ENG}} * [[Zhao Zong-Yuan]] (b. 1986) {{AUS}} {{col-end}}
===Woman Grandmaster=== In 2008 FIDE awarded the title [[Woman Grandmaster]] to the following players:<ref name="FIDE 2Q2008 titles"/><ref name="FIDE 3Q2008 titles"/> {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * [[Nino Batsiashvili]] (b. 1987) {{GEO}} * [[Elizaveta Borisova]] (b. 1984) {{RUS}} * [[Tatiana Fatianova]] (b. 1984) {{RUS}} * [[Mary Ann Gomes]] (b. 1989) {{IND}} {{col-break}} * [[Huang Qian]] (b. 1986) {{CHN}} * [[Monika Krupa]] (b. 1977) {{POL}} * [[Eva Kulovana]] (b. 1987) {{CZE}} * [[Thanh Tu Le]] (b. 1985) {{VNM}} {{col-break}} * [[Kateřina Němcová]] (b. 1990) {{CZE}} * [[Anna Rudolf]] (b. 1978) {{HUN}} {{col-end}} <!-- FIDE rating cards for Krupa and Rudolf show WIM titles as of 2008-03-31 but 2nd Qtr Presidents Board says WGM titles were awarded -->
==Deaths== * January 17 – [[Bobby Fischer]], 64, the 11th [[World Chess Championship|World Champion]], dies in [[Iceland]]. * May 24 – [[Bukhuti Gurgenidze]], 74, [[Georgian people|Georgian]] GM and many time [[Georgian Chess Championship|Georgian Champion]]. * June 9 – [[Karen Asrian]], 28, [[Armenia]]n GM, three times [[Armenian Chess Championship|Armenian Chess Champion]], dies of a suspected heart attack in [[Yerevan]]. * August 10 – [[Igor Zakharevich]], 25, Russian GM.<ref name="twic720">{{cite web|last=Crowther|first=Mark|date=25 August 2008|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 720|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic720.html|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * August 20 – [[Mario Bertok]], 78, [[Croatia]]n IM dies in a swimming accident in [[Jarun Lake]], Zagreb.<ref name="twic720"/> * August 20/21 – [[Vladimir Bukal]], 68, Croatian IM dies overnight in Zagreb. Bukal won the 2002 [[European Senior Chess Championship|European Senior Championship]].<ref name="twic720"/> * November 29 – [[Robert Wade (chess player)|Robert Wade]], 87, winner of multiple New Zealand and British chess championships, IM and International Arbiter, dies in London of pneumonia. * December 10 – [[Mark Diesen]], 51, American IM and 1976 [[World Junior Chess Championship|World Junior Champion]]. * December 20 – [[Albin Planinc]], 64, Yugoslav/Slovenian GM.<ref name="twic737">{{cite web|last=Crowther|first=Mark|date=22 December 2008|title=THE WEEK IN CHESS 737|url=http://www.theweekinchess.com/html/twic737.html|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> * December 24 – [[Hugh Myers]], 78, American master and writer on unorthodox openings, dies in [[Davenport, Iowa]].
==See also== * [[2008 in games]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
